questions.prompt: What characterised the Bronze Age?
options: People were farmers who lived in large villages
People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs
questions.explanation: During the Bronze Age people lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.

questions.prompt: What name is given to the elected members of the Scottish Parliament?
questions.explanation: Elected members of the Scottish Parliament are known as Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs).

questions.prompt: Which game do people usually play at Halloween?
questions.explanation: During Halloween young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play ‘trick or treat’.

questions.prompt: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public
options: Both, the House of Commons and House of Lords
All of the above are false
questions.explanation: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

questions.prompt: What is the most well-known gallery in Wales?
questions.explanation: In the UK, some of the most well-known galleries are The National Gallery, Tate Britain and Tate Modern in London, the National Museum in Cardiff, and the National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh.

questions.prompt: The Man Booker Prize for Fiction is awarded annually for the best fiction novel written by an author from:
options: The European Union, Zambia or Zimbabwe
The Commonwealth, the USA or Australia
The European Union, Canada or Australia
questions.explanation: The Man Booker Prize for Fiction is awarded annually for the best fiction novel written by an author from the Commonwealth, Ireland or Zimbabwe. It has been awarded since 1968.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements regarding Gaelic language is TRUE?
options: In Wales, Gaelic is spoken in some parts of the coast
In Scotland, Gaelic is spoken everywhere
In Scotland, Gaelic is spoken in some parts of the Highlands and Islands
In Wales, Gaelic is the main language
questions.explanation: In Scotland, Gaelic is spoken in some parts of the Highlands and Islands, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic.

questions.prompt: Participation in community life is a fundamental principle of British life.
questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of British life include: participation in community life.

questions.prompt: How many British citizens left the country between 1853 and 1913?
questions.explanation: Between 1853 and 1913, as many as 13 million British citizens left the country.

questions.prompt: Where was the main Olympic site for the 2012 Games?
questions.explanation: The main Olympic site for the 2012 Games was in Stratford, East London.

questions.prompt: Who forms the shadow cabinet?
options: Senior opposition MPs appointed by the leader of the opposition
Junior opposition MPs appointed by the leader of the governing party
Junior opposition MPs appointed by the leader of the opposition
questions.explanation: The leader of the opposition also appoints senior opposition MPs to be ‘shadow ministers’. They form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

questions.prompt: Who directed the movie ‘Brief Encounter’ in 1945?
questions.explanation: Brief Encounter (1945) was directed by David Lean.

questions.prompt: Who was the leader of the English Republic?
questions.explanation: Oliver Cromwell was the leader of the English republic.

questions.prompt: According to the 2011 Census, what percentage of the population identified themselves as Hindu?
questions.explanation: In the 2011 Census, 59% of people identified themselves as Christian. Much smaller proportions identified themselves as Muslim (4.8%), Hindu (1.5%), Sikh (0.8%), Jewish or Buddhist (both less than 0.5%).

questions.prompt: People in the UK have to pay tax on any earnings from (choose THREE options)?
options: Income from property, savings and dividends
questions.explanation: People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes: wages from paid employment, profits from self-employment, taxable benefits, pensions and income from property, savings and dividends.

questions.prompt: How many devolved administrations are there in the UK?
questions.explanation: There are three devolved administrations in the UK, these include: the Welsh Assembly, the Scottish Parliament and the Northern Ireland Assembly.

questions.prompt: Who is responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that trials are conducted fairly?
options: The Prime Minister and the MPs
questions.explanation: Judges (who are together called ‘the judiciary’) are responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that trials are conducted fairly.

questions.prompt: How often do people who are 70 years old or over need to renew their driving licence?
questions.explanation: Drivers can use their driving licence until they are 70 years old. After that, the licence is valid for three years at a time.

questions.prompt: Where was Margaret Thatcher born?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher was the daughter of a grocer from Grantham in Lincolnshire.

questions.prompt: Where are the Welsh government and National Assembly for Wales based?
questions.explanation: The Welsh government and National Assembly for Wales are based in Cardiff, the capital city of Wales.

questions.prompt: Jenson Button is a famous:
questions.explanation: Jenson Button is a famous Formula 1 driver.

questions.prompt: Who introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan by which Wales was annexed to the Crown of England in 1284?
questions.explanation: In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.

questions.prompt: When was the Brexit referendum held?
questions.explanation: The Brexit referendum was held on 23 June 2016.

questions.prompt: In the UK, alcohol cannot be sold to anyone under the age of:
questions.explanation: It is a criminal offence to sell alcohol to anyone who is under 18 or to buy alcohol for people who are under the age of 18. (There is one exception: people aged 16 or over can drink alcohol with a meal in a hotel or restaurant.
